summary: Medulloblastoma is a common type of primary malignant brain cancer in children, originating in the cerebellum or posterior fossa. It is an invasive, rapidly growing tumor that spreads through cerebrospinal fluid and can metastasize to the brain and spinal cord. Historically classified as a PNET, it is now recognized as distinct.
causes: WNT tumors originate from the lower rhombic lip of the brainstem
SHH tumors originate from the external granular layer
Cerebellar stem cells prevented from dividing and differentiating
Mutations in Patched, Sufu, Smoothened, or other genes in the Sonic Hedgehog pathway
Amplification of the Sonic Hedgehog pathway
Mutations in CTNNB1, PTCH1, MLL2, SMARCA4, DDX3X, CTDNEP1, KDM6A, and TBR1
Disrupted MYC, Notch, BMP, and TGF-β signaling pathways
diagnosis: T1- and T2-weighted MRI with heterogeneous enhancement
Location adjacent to and extension into the fourth ventricle
Histology: solid, pink-gray, well circumscribed, very cellular, high mitotic activity, little cytoplasm, tendency to form clusters and rosettes
Ruling out atypical teratoid rhabdoid tumor
treatments: Maximal surgical removal of the tumor
